rows.text:
Kitab al-Ayn{{#tag:ref| The name means "Book of the [[Ayin|Ayn (Letter)]]". |group=n}}
({{lang-ar|كتاب العين}})

Al-Khalil ibn Ahmad al-Farahidi
({{lang-ar|الخليل بن أحمد الفراهيدي}})
(b. 718 - d. 791)
8th century
Kitab al-Ayn was the first dictionary for the Arabic language.

Abu Amr al-Shaybani
({{lang-ar|أبو عمرو الشيباني}})
(b. ca. 738 - d. 828)
8-9th century
The only copy is in the El Escorial Library.

Ibn Duraid
({{lang-ar|ابن دريد}})
(b. 838 - d. 933)
9-10th century
The dictionary was inspired in part by the earlier dictionary Kitab al-Ayn of al-Farahidi.

Tahdhib al-Lugha{{#tag:ref| The name means "Refinement of Language". |group=n}}
({{lang-ar|تهذيب اللغة}})

Abu Manshur al-Azhari al-Harawi
({{lang-ar|أبو منصور الأزهري الهروي}})
(b. 895 - d. 981)
10th century
The dictionary is important as a source of the Lisan al-Arab.

Al-Muhit fi al-Lugha{{#tag:ref| The name means "Ocean in Language". |group=n}}
({{lang-ar|المحيط في اللغة}})

Al-Sahib ibn Abbad
({{lang-ar|الصاحب بن عبّاد}})
(b. 938 - d. 995)
10th century

Ismail ibn Hammad al-Jawhari
({{lang-ar|إسماعيل بن حماد الجوهري}})
(b. ? - d. 1009)
10-11th century
It contains about 40,000 dictionary entries.
The author died at Nishapur while attempting flight.

Ibn Sidah
({{lang-ar|ابن سيده}})
(b. 1007 - d. 1066)
11th century
The author was a blind man.

Lisan al-Arab{{#tag:ref| The name means "The tongue of the Arabs". |group=n}}
({{lang-ar|لسان العرب}})

Ibn Manzur
({{lang-ar|ابن منظور}})
(b. 1233 - d. 1312)
The dictionary was completed in 1290.
It contains about 80,000 dictionary entries.

Al-Firuzabadi
({{lang-ar|الفيروزآبادي}})
(b. 1329 - d. 1414)
The dictionary was completed in 1410.
It contains about 60,000 dictionary entries.
The dictionary served as the basis of later European dictionaries of Arabic.

Al-Murtada al-Zabidi
({{lang-ar|المرتضى الزبيدي}})
(b. 1731 - d. 1790)
The dictionary was completed in 1774.
It contains about 120,000 dictionary entries.

Butrus al-Bustani
({{lang-ar|بطرس البستاني}})
(b. 1819 - d. 1883)
The dictionary was completed in 1870.
The author had dedicated the work to the Sultan Abdulaziz. The sultan awarded him with a higher medal and 250 golden liras.

Lexicon of the Modern Arabic Language
({{lang-ar|معجم اللغة العربية المعاصرة}})
Ahmad Mukhtar Omar
